org.eel.kitchen.jsonschema.ref

Class JsonPointer

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.eel.kitchen.jsonschema.ref.JsonFragment
      • org.eel.kitchen.jsonschema.ref.JsonPointer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Comparable<JsonPointer>

    public final class JsonPointer
extends JsonFragment
implements Comparable<JsonPointer>
    Implementation of IETF JSON Pointer draft, version 3

    JSON Pointer is an IETF draft defining a way to address paths within JSON documents. Paths apply to container objects, ie arrays or nodes. For objects, path elements are property names. For arrays, they are the index in the array (starting from 0).

    The general syntax is #/path/elements/here. A path element is referred to as a "reference token" in the specification.

    The difficulty with JSON Pointer is that any JSON String is valid as an object's property name. These are all valid:

    • "" -- the empty string;
    • "/";
    • "0";
    • "-1";
    • ".", "..", "../..".

    The latter example is the reason why a JSON Pointer is always absolute.

    All instances of this class are immutable (therefore thread safe).

      • append

        public JsonPointer append(String element)
        Append a path element to this pointer. Returns a new instance.
        Parameters:
        element - the element to append
        Returns:
        a new instance with the element appended

      • append

        public JsonPointer append(int index)
        Append an array index to this pointer. Returns a new instance.

        Note that the index validity is NOT checked for (ie, you can append -1 if you want to -- don't do that)

        Parameters:
        index - the index to add
        Returns:
        a new instance with the index appended

      • decode

        private static void decode(String input,
          ImmutableList.Builder<String> builder)
                    throws JsonSchemaException
        Initialize the object

        We read the string sequentially, a slash, then a reference token, then a slash, etc. Bail out if the string is malformed.

        Parameters:
        input - Input string, guaranteed not to be JSON/URI encoded
        builder - the list builder
        Throws:
        JsonSchemaException - the input is not a valid JSON Pointer

      • getNextRefToken

        private static String getNextRefToken(String input)
                               throws JsonSchemaException
        Grab a (cooked) reference token from an input string

        This method is only called from decode(String, ImmutableList.Builder), after a delimiter (/) has been swallowed up. The input string is therefore guaranteed to start with a reference token, which may be empty.

        Parameters:
        input - the input string
        Returns:
        the cooked reference token
        Throws:
        JsonSchemaException - the string is malformed

      • refTokenDecode

        private static String refTokenDecode(String cooked)
        Turn a cooked reference token into a raw reference token

        This means we replace all occurrences of ~0 with ~, and all occurrences of ~1 with /.

        It is called from decode(java.lang.String, com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList.Builder<java.lang.String>), in order to push a token into elements.

        Parameters:
        cooked - the cooked token
        Returns:
        the raw token

      • refTokenEncode

        private static String refTokenEncode(String raw)
        Make a cooked reference token out of a raw element token

        Used to build new pointer instances when called from (String) or append(int), in order to build fullPointer.

        Parameters:
        raw - the raw token
        Returns:
        the cooked token
